Tulsi Gabbard.passage: Tulsi Gabbard is an American politician and military veteran who served as the U.S. Representative for Hawaii's 2nd congressional district from 2013 to 2021. She is a member of the Democratic Party and was the first Hindu member of Congress. Gabbard was born in American Samoa and raised in Hawaii. She served in the Hawaii Army National Guard from 2003 to 2020, including two tours of duty in the Middle East. Gabbard was elected to the Hawaii House of Representatives in 2002 at the age of 21, becoming the youngest woman ever elected to a U.S. state legislature. She served in the Hawaii House until 2004, when she was elected to the Honolulu City Council. In 2010, Gabbard deployed to Iraq with the Hawaii Army National Guard, and upon her return, she ran for and was elected to the U.S. House of Representatives in 2012. During her time in Congress, Gabbard focused on issues related to foreign policy, national security, and veterans' affairs. She was a vocal critic of U.S. military intervention in Syria and advocated for a non-interventionist foreign policy. Gabbard also introduced legislation to address issues facing veterans, including mental health care and homelessness. In 2019, Gabbard announced her candidacy for the Democratic nomination for President of the United States in the 2020 election. She faced criticism for her past opposition to same-sex marriage and her meeting with Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. Gabbard ultimately suspended her campaign in March 2020 and endorsed Joe Biden. Gabbard did not seek re-election to Congress in 2020 and left office in January 2021. She has since been involved in various political and advocacy efforts, including speaking out against cancel culture and advocating for criminal justice reform.

The party has also been associated with progressive social policies, such as support for same-sex marriage, abortion rights, and drug policy reform. McCain graduated from the United States Naval Academy in 1958 and became a naval aviator. He was shot down during the Vietnam War and spent over five years as a prisoner of war. After retiring from the military, McCain entered politics and was elected to the House of Representatives in 1982. He was later elected to the Senate in 1986 and served as the chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee from 1997 to 2001 and again from 2003 to 2007. McCain was known for his independent and maverick approach to politics, often breaking with his party on issues such as campaign finance reform, immigration, and climate change. He was also a strong advocate for human rights and was a vocal critic of authoritarian regimes around the world. McCain died on August 25, 2018, at the age of 81, after a battle with brain cancer.

Muammar Gaddafi..passage: Muammar Gaddafi was a Libyan revolutionary, politician, and political theorist. He governed Libya as Revolutionary Chairman of the Libyan Arab Republic from 1969 to 1977, then as the "Brotherly Leader" of the Great Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya from 1977 to 2011. He was initially ideologically committed to Arab nationalism and Arab socialism but later came to rule under his own Third International Theory. Gaddafi was born near Sirte to an impoverished Bedouin family. He became an Arab nationalist while at school in Sabha, later enrolling in the Royal Military Academy, Benghazi. Within the military, he founded a revolutionary cell which, in a 1969 coup, overthrew the Western-backed monarchy of Idris I. Gaddafi was initially hailed as a hero by some in Libya and elsewhere for his role in ousting the monarchy, but he quickly became known for his eccentric and often brutal style of governance. He established a political philosophy known as the Third International Theory, which he described as a hybrid of socialism and Islam. He was also known for his support of various revolutionary movements and his opposition to Israel. Gaddafi's rule was characterized by authoritarianism, political repression, and human rights abuses. He was accused of ordering the Lockerbie bombing in 1988, which killed 270 people, and of supporting various terrorist groups. In 2011, a popular uprising against Gaddafi's rule broke out, which was supported by NATO forces. Gaddafi was captured and killed by rebel forces in October of that year. His legacy remains controversial, with some in Libya and elsewhere viewing him as a hero and others as a tyrant.

Supreme Court..passage: The Supreme Court of the United States is the highest court in the federal judiciary of the United States. Established pursuant to Article III of the U.S. Constitution in 1789, it has original jurisdiction over a small range of cases, such as suits between two or more states, and those involving ambassadors. It also has ultimate appellate jurisdiction over all federal court and state court cases that involve a point of federal constitutional or statutory law. The Court has the power of judicial review, the ability to invalidate a statute for violating a provision of the Constitution or an executive act for being unlawful. However, it may act only within the context of a case in an area of law over which it has jurisdiction. The Court may decide cases having political overtones, but it has ruled that it does not have power to decide nonjusticiable political questions. Each year it agrees to hear about 100-150 of the more than 7,000 cases that it is asked to review. Typically, the Court hears cases that have been decided in either an appropriate U.S. Court of Appeals or the highest court in a given state (if the state court decided a Constitutional issue). The Court may also accept cases through the certiorari process, by which four justices agree to hear a particular case. The Court meets in the Supreme Court Building in Washington, D.C. Its law enforcement arm is the Supreme Court Police. It is sometimes colloquially referred to by the acronym SCOTUS.

Congress..passage: Congress is the legislative branch of the United States federal government, consisting of two chambers: the Senate and the House of Representatives. The Congress meets in the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C. Both senators and representatives are chosen through direct election, though vacancies in the Senate may be filled by a gubernatorial appointment. Members are usually affiliated to the Republican Party or to the Democratic Party, and only rarely to a third-party or as independents. The Congress has the power to pass federal laws, declare war, regulate commerce, and approve or reject presidential appointments and treaties. It also has the power of the purse, which includes the ability to levy taxes and appropriate funds for federal programs. The Senate has the additional power of confirming federal judges and executive branch officials. The House of Representatives has the sole power to initiate revenue bills, impeach federal officials, and elect the President in the case of an electoral college tie. The Congress is considered a co-equal branch of government with the executive and judicial branches, and is essential to the functioning of the American system of checks and balances.

China..passage: China, officially the People's Republic of China, is a country in East Asia. It is the world's most populous country, with a population of around 1.4 billion. Covering approximately 9.6 million square kilometers, it is the world's third or fourth-largest country by area. The country is officially divided into 23 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. China emerged as one of the world's earliest civilizations, in the fertile basin of the Yellow River in the North China Plain. For millennia, China's political system was based on hereditary monarchies, or dynasties, beginning with the semi-legendary Xia dynasty in 21st century BCE. Since then, China has expanded, fractured, and re-unified numerous times. In the 3rd century BCE, the Qin reunited core China and established the first Chinese empire. The succeeding Han dynasty, which ruled from 206 BCE until 220 CE, saw some of the most advanced technology at that time, including papermaking and the compass, along with agricultural and medical improvements. The invention of gunpowder and movable type in the Tang dynasty (618–907) and Northern Song Dynasty (960–1127) completed the Four Great Inventions. Tang culture spread widely in Asia, as the new Silk Route brought traders to as far as Mesopotamia and the Horn of Africa. The Qing dynasty, which lasted from 1644 until 1912, was the last imperial dynasty of China. In the late 19th century, the Qing dynasty was overthrown following the Boxer Rebellion, which was itself crushed by an international alliance led by the Eight-Nation Alliance. The establishment of the Republic of China in 1912 led to the Chinese Civil War and the division of China into the two political entities of the PRC and the ROC. The PRC is a one-party state governed by the Communist Party of China, with its seat of government in the capital city of Beijing. It exercises jurisdiction over 22 provinces, five autonomous regions, four direct-controlled municipalities (Beijing, Tianjin, Shanghai, and Chongqing), and the special administrative regions of Hong Kong and Macau. The PRC also claims Taiwan – which is controlled by the ROC – as its 23rd province, a claim controversial due to the complex political status of Taiwan and the unresolved Chinese Civil War.

Germany..passage: Germany, officially known as the Federal Republic of Germany, is a country located in Central Europe. It is bordered by Denmark to the north, Poland and the Czech Republic to the east, Austria and Switzerland to the south, and France, Luxembourg, Belgium, and the Netherlands to the west. With a population of over 83 million people, Germany is the second-most populous country in Europe after Russia and the seventh-most populous country in the world. Its capital and largest city is Berlin. Germany has a rich history and culture, with roots dating back to the Holy Roman Empire. It has been a major player in world events, including both World War I and World War II. After the latter, Germany was divided into two separate countries, East Germany and West Germany, until reunification in 1990. Today, Germany is a federal parliamentary republic and a member of the European Union, NATO, and the United Nations. Germany is known for its contributions to science, technology, and the arts. It is home to some of the world's most renowned universities, including the University of Heidelberg and the Technical University of Munich. Germany is also famous for its automotive industry, with brands such as BMW, Mercedes-Benz, and Volkswagen. The country is also known for its beer, wine, and cuisine, which varies by region. Germany has a strong economy, with a highly skilled workforce and a focus on innovation. It is the fourth-largest economy in the world by nominal GDP and the fifth-largest by purchasing power parity. The country is a leader in renewable energy, with a goal of phasing out nuclear power by 2022. Germany is a popular tourist destination, with attractions such as the Brandenburg Gate, Neuschwanstein Castle, and the Berlin Wall. The country is also home to numerous museums, including the Berlin Museum Island and the German National Museum. Germany's natural beauty can be seen in its many parks and forests, including the Black Forest and the Bavarian Alps.

East Germany..passage: East Germany, officially known as the German Democratic Republic (GDR), was a state that existed from 1949 to 1990, when the eastern portion of Germany was part of the Eastern Bloc during the Cold War. It was formed from the Soviet occupation zone of Germany, which was established in 1945. The GDR was a socialist state and a member of the Warsaw Pact. The country was ruled by the Socialist Unity Party of Germany (SED), which was led by Erich Honecker from 1971 until the fall of the Berlin Wall in 1989. The GDR was known for its strict border controls, censorship, and surveillance of its citizens. The country's economy was centrally planned and heavily subsidized by the Soviet Union. Despite this, the GDR was able to achieve some economic success, particularly in the areas of heavy industry and engineering. However, the country was plagued by shortages of consumer goods and a lack of political freedom. In 1989, a wave of protests swept across the GDR, culminating in the fall of the Berlin Wall on November 9th. This event marked the beginning of the end for the GDR, and the country was officially dissolved on October 3rd, 1990, when it was reunified with West Germany.

Today, Leningrad State University is known as Saint Petersburg State University and remains one of the leading universities in Russia, with a strong reputation for academic excellence and scientific research. Its alumni include many prominent figures in politics, science, and culture, both in Russia and around the world.

It is headquartered in Lubyanka Square, Moscow's centre, in the main building of the former KGB. The Director of the FSB since 2008 is army general Aleksandr Bortnikov. The two major structural components of the former KGB that remain administratively independent of the FSB are the Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR) and the State Guards (FSO). The FSB is mainly responsible for internal security of the Russian state, counterintelligence, and the fight against organized crime, terrorism, and drug smuggling, whereas overseas espionage is the primary responsibility of the Russian Foreign Intelligence Service. However, the FSB's FAPSI (Federal Agency of Government Communications and Information) units are responsible for the surveillance and interception of communication within Russia and the FSB Directorate S is responsible for conducting espionage activities outside of Russia.

Yeltsin was born in 1931 in the village of Butka, in the Sverdlovsk Oblast of the Soviet Union. He studied construction engineering at the Ural Polytechnic Institute and later worked as a construction foreman. In 1965, he joined the Communist Party of the Soviet Union and quickly rose through the ranks, becoming the first secretary of the Sverdlovsk Oblast Party Committee in 1976. Yeltsin gained national attention in 1985 when he criticized the slow pace of reform under Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev. He was later dismissed from his position as the first secretary of the Moscow Communist Party in 1987, but he continued to speak out against the Soviet government. In 1990, Yeltsin was elected president of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, and he played a key role in the dissolution of the Soviet Union the following year. As president of the Russian Federation, Yeltsin implemented a series of economic reforms, including privatization and market liberalization, but his presidency was also marked by political turmoil and economic instability. Yeltsin resigned from office in 1999, and he died in 2007 at the age of 76.

Crimea..passage: Crimea is a peninsula located in the Black Sea, in Eastern Europe. It is currently administered by Russia, but its sovereignty is disputed by Ukraine and recognized as Ukrainian territory by most of the international community. Crimea has a rich history, having been inhabited by various peoples throughout the centuries, including the Greeks, Romans, Byzantines, Tatars, and Russians. It was annexed by the Russian Empire in the late 18th century and became part of the Soviet Union in 1921. In 1954, Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev transferred Crimea from the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic to the Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic. After the collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991, Crimea became part of independent Ukraine. However, tensions between the ethnic Russian population of Crimea and the Ukrainian government have been high since then, culminating in the 2014 Ukrainian revolution and the subsequent annexation of Crimea by Russia. The annexation has been widely condemned by the international community, and sanctions have been imposed on Russia as a result. The situation in Crimea remains tense, with ongoing human rights abuses and political repression.

The BRI is divided into two main components: the Silk Road Economic Belt, which focuses on land-based infrastructure projects, and the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road, which focuses on maritime infrastructure projects. The initiative has been met with both praise and criticism, with some countries viewing it as a way to boost their economies and others expressing concerns about China's growing influence and potential debt traps. Despite these concerns, the BRI has continued to expand, with China investing billions of dollars in infrastructure projects around the world.

Indigenous Australians inhabited the continent for about 65,000 years prior to the first arrival of Dutch explorers in the early 17th century, who named it New Holland. In 1770, James Cook claimed the east coast of Australia for Great Britain, and the British established a penal colony in New South Wales in 1788. The population grew steadily in the following years, and by the 1850s, Australia was experiencing a gold rush, which led to the establishment of several new cities. Australia is a highly developed country with a strong economy and a high standard of living. It is a member of the United Nations, G20, Commonwealth of Nations, ANZUS, Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), World Trade Organization, Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, and the Pacific Islands Forum. Australia is also known for its unique flora and fauna, including kangaroos, koalas, and the Great Barrier Reef. Australia is a constitutional monarchy with a parliamentary system of government. The Queen of Australia, currently Queen Elizabeth II, is also the monarch of 15 other Commonwealth realms. The Australian government is divided into three branches: the executive, legislative, and judicial. The Prime Minister is the head of government, and the Governor-General is the representative of the monarch. Australia has a diverse and multicultural society, with a significant Indigenous population and immigrants from all over the world. English is the official language, and Christianity is the most widely practiced religion. However, Australia is also known for its secularism and commitment to religious freedom.

Harvard University..passage: Harvard University is a private Ivy League research university in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Established in 1636 and named for its first benefactor, clergyman John Harvard, Harvard is the oldest institution of higher learning in the United States and among the most prestigious in the world. The Massachusetts colonial legislature, the General Court, authorized Harvard's founding. In its early years, Harvard College primarily trained Congregational and Unitarian clergy, although it has never been formally affiliated with any denomination. Its curriculum and student body were gradually secularized during the 18th century, and by the 19th century, Harvard had emerged as the central cultural establishment among Boston elites. Following the American Civil War, President Charles W. Eliot's long tenure (1869–1909) transformed the college and affiliated professional schools into a modern research university; Harvard became a founding member of the Association of American Universities in 1900. James B. Conant led the university through the Great Depression and World War II; he liberalized admissions after the war. The university is composed of ten academic faculties plus the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. Arts and Sciences, which includes Harvard College and the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, is the largest of the ten faculties and is the only division to offer undergraduate education. Harvard also has five additional academic divisions: Harvard Business School, Harvard Divinity School, Harvard Graduate School of Education, Harvard Law School, and Harvard Medical School. Harvard's endowment is valued at $41.9 billion, making it the largest of any academic institution. Endowment income helps enable the undergraduate college to admit students regardless of financial need and provide generous financial aid with no loans The Harvard Library is the world's largest academic library system, comprising 79 individual libraries holding about 20.4 million items.

United Nations..passage: The United Nations (UN) is an intergovernmental organization that aims to maintain international peace and security, develop friendly relations among nations, achieve international cooperation, and be a center for harmonizing the actions of nations. It was established after World War II in 1945, with the aim of preventing future wars and promoting cooperation among countries. The UN has 193 member states, and its headquarters is located in New York City. The organization is composed of six main bodies: the General Assembly, the Security Council, the International Court of Justice, the Economic and Social Council, the Secretariat, and the Trusteeship Council (which is currently inactive). The UN also has specialized agencies and programs, such as the World Health Organization, the United Nations Children's Fund, and the United Nations Development Programme. The UN has played a significant role in promoting human rights, fighting poverty, and addressing global issues such as climate change and terrorism. However, it has also faced criticism for its perceived inefficiency and lack of accountability. Despite these challenges, the UN remains an important forum for international cooperation and diplomacy.

Harvard..passage: Harvard University is a private Ivy League research university in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Established in 1636 and named for its first benefactor, clergyman John Harvard, Harvard is the oldest institution of higher learning in the United States and among the most prestigious in the world. The Massachusetts colonial legislature, the General Court, authorized Harvard's founding. In its early years, Harvard College primarily trained Congregational and Unitarian clergy, although it has never been formally affiliated with any denomination. Its curriculum and student body were gradually secularized during the 18th century, and by the 19th century, Harvard had emerged as the central cultural establishment among Boston elites. Following the American Civil War, President Charles W. Eliot's long tenure (1869–1909) transformed the college and affiliated professional schools into a modern research university; Harvard became a founding member of the Association of American Universities in 1900. James B. Conant led the university through the Great Depression and World War II; he liberalized admissions after the war. The university is composed of ten academic faculties plus the Radcliffe Institute for Advanced Study. Arts and Sciences, which includes Harvard College, the Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, and the Division of Continuing Education, is the largest faculty. Harvard's endowment is valued at $41.9 billion, making it the largest of any academic institution. Endowment income helps enable the undergraduate college to admit students regardless of financial need and provide generous financial aid with no loans The Harvard Library is the world's largest academic library system, comprising 79 individual libraries holding about 20.4 million items.

Instagram..passage: Instagram is a photo and video sharing social networking service owned by Facebook, Inc. It was created by Kevin Systrom and Mike Krieger, and launched in October 2010 exclusively on iOS. A version for Android devices was released a year and half later, in April 2012, followed by a feature-limited website interface in November 2012, and apps for Windows 10 Mobile and Windows 10 in April 2016 and October 2016 respectively. The app allows users to upload photos and videos to the service, which can be edited with various filters, and organized with tags and location information. An account's posts can be shared publicly or with pre-approved followers. Users can browse other users' content by tags and locations, and view trending content. Users can "like" photos, and follow other users to add their content to a feed. The service was originally distinguished by only allowing content to be framed in a square (1:1) aspect ratio with 640 pixels to match the display width of the iPhone 4, 4s, 5, 5s and SE. In 2015, these restrictions were eased with an increase to 1080 pixels. The service also added messaging features, the ability to include multiple images or videos in a single post, as well as "Stories"—similar to its main competitor Snapchat—which allows users to post photos and videos to a sequential feed, with each post accessible by others for 24 hours each. As of January 2019, the Stories feature is used by 500 million users daily.

Bloomberg L.P..passage: Bloomberg L.P. is a privately held financial, software, data, and media company headquartered in Midtown Manhattan, New York City. It was founded by Michael Bloomberg in 1981, with the help of Thomas Secunda, Duncan MacMillan, Charles Zegar, and a 30% ownership investment by Merrill Lynch. Bloomberg L.P. provides financial software tools and enterprise applications such as analytics and equity trading platform, data services, and news to financial companies and organizations through the Bloomberg Terminal (via its Bloomberg Professional Service), its core revenue-generating product. Bloomberg L.P. also includes a wire service (Bloomberg News), a global television network (Bloomberg Television), digital websites, radio stations (Bloomberg Radio), subscription-only newsletters, and three magazines: Bloomberg Businessweek, Bloomberg Markets, and Bloomberg Pursuits. In 2019, Bloomberg L.P. employed approximately 20,000 people in more than 120 countries.

Brown University..passage: Brown University is a private Ivy League research university in Providence, Rhode Island. Founded in 1764 as the College in the English Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations, it is the seventh-oldest institution of higher education in the United States and one of the nine colonial colleges chartered before the American Revolution. At its foundation, Brown was the first college in the United States to accept students regardless of their religious affiliation. Its engineering program, established in 1847, was the first in what is now known as the Ivy League. Brown's New Curriculum—sometimes referred to in education theory as the Brown Curriculum—was adopted by faculty vote in 1969 after a period of student lobbying; the New Curriculum eliminated mandatory "general education" distribution requirements, made students "the architects of their own syllabus," and allowed them to take any course for a grade of satisfactory or unrecorded no-credit. In 1971, Brown's coordinate women's institution, Pembroke College, was fully merged into the university. Undergraduate admissions is highly selective, with an acceptance rate of 6.9% for the class of 2024. The university comprises the College, the Graduate School, Alpert Medical School, the School of Engineering, the School of Public Health, and the School of Professional Studies (which includes the IE Brown Executive MBA program). Brown's international programs are organized through the Watson Institute for International and Public Affairs, and the university is academically affiliated with the Marine Biological Laboratory and the Rhode Island School of Design. The Brown/RISD Dual Degree Program, offered in conjunction with the Rhode Island School of Design, is a five-year course that awards degrees from both institutions. Brown's main campus is located in the College Hill Historic District in the city of Providence, the third-largest city in New England. The University's neighborhood is a federally listed architectural district with a dense concentration of Colonial-era buildings. The Rhode Island State House and Providence Place Mall are located within walking distance of the campus. Brown's athletic teams are known as the Brown Bears and are members of the Ivy League. They have won 32 Ivy League championships since the league's inception in 1954. The women's field hockey team has won six national championships since 1975.

Committee on Rules..passage: The Committee on Rules is a committee of the United States House of Representatives responsible for determining under what rule other Committee’s bills will come to the floor. The Committee is often considered one of the most powerful committees as it has the ability to effectively control the House floor. The Committee is made up of nine members, five from the majority party and four from the minority party. The Chairman of the Committee is typically a member of the majority party and is appointed by the Speaker of the House. The Committee meets regularly to consider and report on rules for House floor consideration of bills and resolutions. The Committee also has the power to grant special rules that allow for expedited consideration of legislation. The Committee on Rules plays a critical role in the legislative process and is often involved in shaping the final form of legislation before it is voted on by the full House.
